captions.text: STAR MEDIA presents
Come on, let me do it.
Hold on, Vasya.
Buzz off, youíll screw everything up.

Zhenya. Iím asking you as
a friend: let me go first.
All right.
Damn it.
Hey there, curly-haired beauty.

I can see youíve got great
legs and lots of bags.
Can you see the poet in me yet?

See, you were in too big of a
hurry and you broke your heel.
The heelís got a secret, doesnít it?
Very funny.
Can I have the name of my beauty?
Iím not ìyourî beauty, you know.

But the beauty does have a
name? Even if she isnít mine yet.
Yes!
Well?
My name is Mila.
You know, I just knew it would be Mila!

Seriously, I knew it.
Listen, try to guess my name.
Look, Iím in a hurry.

Itís not that hard. Itís either
Aleksandr, Vasiliy or Yevgeniy.
What do you think?
Yevgeniy.
Why Yevgeniy?

I donít know. Aleksandr
is a bit too manly for you.

Vasiliy is too simple.
Yevgeniy fits you.

Hey, you guessed right!
It really is Yevgeniy.
And Vasiliy is my best friendís name.
Heís too simple for me, then?

No, why would he be? You
complement each other.
That must be why youíre friends.

Yep. Iím with him right now,
weíre going to a training session.
And you must be going somewhere, too,
but you have nothing to wear.
Yeah. I have...

Thatís why I have a
great proposition for you.
Can you guess what it is?

Listen, how about when youíve
taken the groceries to your dad,
we go see a movie?
A movie?
Yeah! Why not?
Is Vasiliy coming with us?
Sure thing, Mila!
No, Vasyaís busy.
Present day.
Poor, poor Yevgeniy Ivanovich!
This is going to shake his world.

Heís always been so
well-groomed, so respectable...
Mommy, stop it.
Mila took such good care of him.
Calm down.

Howís he going to live
now that Milaís gone?
Mom! Heís got children.

No, the children will
never replace Mila.

Gala, whatís that grave
doing next to Milaís?
Didnít he choose a proper place?
Mommy, calm down!
Is she going to be there alone,
surrounded by other peopleís graves?
Mommy, you canít cry about everyone!
My condolences.
You jinxed her.
Thank you for coming, Uncle Vasya.
Tell you what, guys.

If anything happens... I mean,
if anything else happens.
Call me right away.
What else can happen? Youíre scaring me.

Donít be scared. The important
thing is to call me right away.
Okay, we will.

Arenít you coming to the
commemoration with us?

No. Iím sorry, your
father is angry at me,
as if I did something wrong.

Well, thatís his own problem.
Uncle Vasya, come with us.
Letís go.

No. I donít want him to
get mad because Iím there.
You will call me, though, right?
Uncle Vasya!
Iíll be at the grave. Okay?
Do you know what just happened?
No. Okay, letís go.

I remember everything, Mila. Iíll
do everything like you wanted.
If they call me.

...so the breast cancer statistics
for women, unfortunately,
arenít very comforting.
Turn the TV off.

My dear opponent has proved
himself to be a qualified doctor,

I thank him for that. But as a
man, he didnít stand the test.

Like thousands of men, there,
on the other side of the screen.
I blame men, and most of all husbands.
Igor, turn the TV off!

I think that men are to blame
for all womenís health problems.
My dear men...

Dad, can I take a few
photos as mementos?
Sure.

Have many of you provided
such conditions for women

that they could watch
their health more closely?

How many times have you come
out in the cold for them...
Thatís your father!
...to hang out the laundry to dry?

I thought this picture was
lost. Turns out it was here.
Throw it out.
Do you know the dangers...

Why do you have to say things
like that? Heís your father!

How many times have you
offered to take your women...
You two look a lot like each other.

...to take a physical? For no
reason, not because sheís sick.

I think he visited us
when we were little.
Nonsense. He couldnít have visited.
...and not just offer that she goes...
Turn the TV off, already!
Heís doing that on purpose.
...my dear men, you can...
Really?
...sometimes...

So I can hear everything.
To make me feel guilty.
Come on, Dad.

I donít see why you didnít
consult me when you were
choosing the place in the cemetery.
What donít you like?
I told you already.
What donít I like?
The way people talk!
Thereís no room next to it, no room!
Mom is alone, buried among other people.

And when itís my turn,
what are you going to do?

Bury me in behind the
ravine at the junkyard?
Since when do you care what people say?
What are you trying to say?
Stop it, you!
Nothing.

I get it, youíre trying
to put it into my head...
Stop it!
...that I didnít love Mom enough, right?
Uncle Vasya did it, right?

So when I would go on
business trips all the time,
earn money, slave away at work,

that was my way of saying
I didnít love Mom? Right?
Business trips, huh?

And then Mother would get
calls after those trips.

Cute female voices
would ask for Zhenya and

get very surprised that you
have a wife and children!
Igor!
ìIgorî what?
What the hell are going on about?

Stop being a hypocrite! We
got in your way all your life.

Got in the way of your
parties, of your fun.
And those women really did call,
Mom just wouldnít tell you about it.
Igor, enough!
And then she would cry at night.

In the kitchen so she
wouldnít wake you up.
Shut your mouth!
What? Let me have my say.
Enough of that!

Dad, donít listen to him.
Donít listen to what he says.
Are you done?
No, Iím not done. Just so you know,

it was Momís decision to be
buried here, next to the old grave,
and no place else.
Just so you know, Iím really glad,

Iím ecstatic that Mom
had a secret from you.
What secret?

I donít know, some secret. But
she said it over six months ago:

she wanted us to bury her
here, and no place else.
She bought the land a long time ago.
And got all the papers for it.
Want me to show them to you?
Whoís buried there? Who?
Some relatives of hers, maybe...

What relatives? We donít have
any relatives in this cemetery!
Dad! Wait up, please! Dad! Dad!

Lena, get your hand
off of me! Take it off!
ìI thought youíd be there forever.î
Whoís there next to you? Huh?
Whoís buried there next to you?

You canít do that! You
canít do that! Stop!
What do you want?
I was sent to you.
From where?

Somewhere where they
know everything about you.

This could sound strange,
but I have a mission with you.
Buzz off!

23 years ago you went on a
business trip to Vladivostok.
You cheated on your wife there.
You spent a whole month in Vladivostok.
Here is the letter you wrote her.

The woman you were with the
whole time in Vladivostok
would call your wife for a long time.

Thatís where your sonís memories
about women calling his Mom

come from. She would
cry a lot after that.
Who are you?
I just told you:

I come from a place where
they know all about you.

Yevgeniy Ivanovich,
letís get out of here.
Letís find some cafe, sit down and talk.
Itís rather cold here, after all.
Hello, dear Mila.
I miss you and our kids very much.
But the situation at work has changed.

I still have to deal
with the train cars.

Iím going to have to
stay here another week.

I donít get it. Where
did you get all this?

Yevgeniy Ivanovich, I
just explained it to you.
These things never vanish for good.

They stay, just like
your deeds and thoughts.
And my mission is to explain it to you.
Youíre interested in the unmarked grave.

It appeared during the
time you were in Vladivostok
on a business trip.
Whoís in it? Who?
I donít know.
Iím just a simple worker.

There are many of us,
and each one has a job.
My job is to protect you.

To keep you from doing
something irrevocable.
How do I find out whoís buried there?
I was told that if you persist,
I could offer you a trip to the past.
I could send you to your wife.

And youíd try to answer all
questions yourself. Do you want it?
Wait a second...
How?

Itís very simple. You wonít
arouse any suspicion in anyone.
So I wonít be myself?

No, youíll be yourself. But you
wonít be as young as your wife.
Youíll be your real age.
Okay, and what if, say... I met myself?
You wonít. You arenít paying attention.

Iíve told you that the grave
youíre interested in appeared

during the time you were in
Vladivostok on a business trip.

Those three weeks are where
weíre going to send you.

And if it goes wrong, the Law
of Obstruction will take effect.

If youíre occupying
Young Yevgeniyís place,

the double cannot approach
the spot you are in.

But I would like to warn
you, Yevgeniy Ivanovich.

If you try to take Young
Yevgeniyís place for good,

that is, if you donít
come back in three weeks,

Young Yevgeniyís fate will
start changing for the worst.

So letís not experiment too
much, Yevgeniy Ivanovich,
we donít need that.

So, do you agree to come to
your wife for three weeks?
Yes.
Okay. This is your new passport.
And the money, too.

Itís real, take it. Put all
this stuff in your briefcase...

ìKotov, Ivan Kapitonovichî?
Whoís this, my father?

Yes. Itís very convenient.
Firstly, you look very similar.
Secondly, heís the same age you are now.
Can he show up there all of a sudden?

You arenít paying any
attention, Yevgeniy Ivanovich.

Iíve told you about the
Law of Obstruction already.
Besides, he never once thought of you.
How is he?
Is he alive? Dead?
Dead.
Itís time, Yevgeniy Ivanovich.
Sir?
Maybe heís a foreigner?
Comrade! Comrade!

Who are you calling comrade?
Look what heís wearing!
Sir?
ìComrade!î

Whoís going to pay for
your ticket, Pushkin?
Heís a foreigner!
Sir!
Do you speak English?
Can you understand Russian?
Yeah, yeah, I can.
Really? Heís from around here!
Dreaming about foreigners all day.

Who hasnít day-dreamed
about foreigners?
Are you okay? How are you feeling?
Not...
Is everything okay?
Itís okay. Iím good.
Pay for the ticket, then.
How much?
What?
The ticket, how much?
Get a load of this guy!
I can see youíre from the Party? Right?

Youíre pretty far removed
from the people, then,

if you donít even know how
much a bus ticket costs.

Iíve been with the people all
my life, Iíve never left them.

Not what Iíd think
looking at your get-up.
Donít be a wise guy.
The ticket is five kopeks.
Hereís your change.
Thank you.
Hello?
Hello?
Hello? Speak up, I canít hear you.
Come on, those veterans again!
My wife is sick!
What does she have to do with anything?
I have a right, do you understand?
Do you have any children?
What do you have?
Look, weíre all in this line.
Theyíre at work now, they canít...
Chestnut braids, Iím going to comb them.
With a fine-tooth comb.
Hey, Shura.
Hello.
Who goes around the tree the fastest?

Whoís it going to be,
whoís it going to be?
Lena?
No, no, thatís it, letís go.
Mila.
Hello.
Hello.
Itís me.
Itís me.
You? Youíre Ivan Kapitonovich?
Right? Youíre Zhenyaís dad?
Yeah.
How did you know?
Itís just that you look like him a lot.
So, did you get my letter? Did you?
I just didnít know where to write,

so I mailed it to two
addresses at random.
A letter?
Thatís right.

Oh, itís raining. Come on, donít
get wet, get under the awning.

Itís just that we didnít
know anything about you.

Zhenyaís mom told him you were
born somewhere around Saratov,

but Zhenya couldnít
remember where exactly,

whether it was in
Ivanovka or Ivantieevka.

So I took a look at the
map and found two places

with similar names
and mailed it to both.
Does he know? Does Zhenya know?

About the letter? No,
he doesnít know anything.
Why didnít you tell him?

It was my decision to introduce
you two to each other. You know?
Why?

Excuse me, but because
I think itís wrong

when father and son donít
talk to each other at all.

And, after all, youíre alive and
well. You take no interest in-
Sorry, thatís none of my business.
And Zhenya isnít home.

Unfortunately, he just
left on a business trip.
Heís in the Far East.
Heíll only be back in about three weeks.

Was that you calling me
about twenty minutes ago?
I just thought it was Zhenya.

Yeah, it was me. I couldnít hear
you, the phone wasnít working.
Mom, he broke the bike!
What did he break again?
Igor, whatís the matter with you?
When Daddy comes back heíll yell at you.
It was her! Her!
When will this end?
It was him!

Who broke it, Igor?
Why are you doing this?
She broke it! She broke my bike.

Hey! What are you slandering
your little sister for?

Well, both of you are a piece
of work. Just like always.
These are our children: Lena, Igor.
It was him!
S youíre telling on each other now, huh?

Go to the house, go.
Iíll be there in a minute.
You must be hungry.

And here I am, keeping
you in the street.

Letís go inside! Iíll
cook you some lunch.

So, where are you from, after
all ñ Ivanovka or Ivanteevka?
Ivanteevka.
Oh, Ivanteevka... I see.
Mila, Iíve been meaning to ask you.
Can I stay at your place or something?

While Iím waiting for
Zhenya. To meet him.

Whenís he supposed to
come, two or three weeks?
Thatís right.
So, what is it? Can I stay?
Of course you can!
Itís just that Zhenya...
He doesnít know I wrote to you.
I donít know how heíll take it.

I see. Youíre afraid
he wonít be very glad?
I donít know.
I mean, Iíd love it if you two met and
actually talked to each other, somehow...

I could tell him I found
you myself, if you want.
You wonít have to make excuses.
Yeah, it would be great.
Itíll be our little secret.

Can you keep a little
secret from your husband?

Not really. I donít have any
secrets from Zhenya, actually.
Do you love him?
Very much.
Owners!
Aunt Varya, is that you?
Yeah.
Hello.
Good afternoon.
Hello.
Bon appetit.
Thank you.

I saw someone walk by. I
thought Yevgeniy came back.
But I think itís too early.
No, that wasnít Zhenya. That was...
Zhenyaís father. Yeah.
Ivan Kapitonovich, meet aunt Varya.
Pleased to meet you.
Pleased to meet you.

So, seems like something
importantís happened here.

Thatís right. Tea?
Thereís also some compote.
No, thank you, thank you.
I donít want anything.

Why did the father remember
his son all of a sudden?

Itís not like he was
terribly interested before.
Aunt Varya!
ìAunt Varyaî what? ìAunt Varyaî what?

Youíre a young girl. Could be
anything. I just want to know.
I want to know the purpose of the trip.

I came here. I want
to see my son at last.
To ask him for forgiveness.
Thatís right. Right...
And whatís your job?
Iím in supplies.
Well, Iíll be! Just like Zhenya.
I can see youíre not exactly poor.
Are you married?
Aunt Varya!
Calm down!
Iím a widower.
I see.

What are you being all silent
for? Why donít you say something?
What can I say? He just got here.
I literally just arrived.

Well, I wanted to tell him about
you, about how nice you were.
Oh come on, now!

You probably wanted to tell him
how I married the granddad, right?
Really now, aunt Varya!

I wanted to tell him how
lucky Zhenya and I are,
living here at your place.
I know what they say about me.

Aunt Varya, stop it! What
are you talking about?

I just wanted to tell him
how lucky we are to have you.

Well... we arenít friends
with your mother for nothing.
Zoya is Milaís mother.

Weíve been working at the
sewing factory together
for twenty years.

And when old man the neighbor
asked me to marry him,
I moved to his place.

And Iím renting my house
to them for 35 rubles.

Do you know how much the
rent is in this suburb?
No less that 40 or 50.

Thank you! Thank you
for helping the kids.
Yeah, I help, unlike some others.
Oh, right, the reason I came here!
That old man of mine got sick...

Itís nothing serious,
but do take care of him.
Sure thing, aunt Varya, no problem.
And where are your kids?
Napping after lunch.
Whatís that?
Right, Iíll go check up on them.

Sorry. Itís all pretty
simple around here.
I watch over her kids, if need be.
Aunt Varya... Can I simply call you Varya?
Of course.
Iíve been meaning to ask you...

Would you happen to
have some light clothes?
Just some work clothes.

You know, to do things
around the house and all that.

Because, as you can see,
I was traveling light,

and Iím afraid Zhenyaís
will be too small for me.
Nails...
Do you have any drying oil?
We donít.
Until when?
Come back in a couple days.
A hammer.
A hammer.
And a handsaw.
...and a handsaw. There you go.
Eight.
The teeth are sharp the handsawís good.
What else?
Oh, a jack plane.
We donít have a jack plane.
Really? Too bad.
And whatís that you have there?
Whatís that there? A jointer-plane?
Yeah, a jointer-plane.
Give me the jointer-plane, then.

The thing is, the boss
put it away for himself.

But in a week weíll
have a new shipment, so...

Can we somehow resolve
this situation quicker?
Well...
How much?
Well... You understand...
Of course I do. How much?
Fifteen.
Deal.
All in all... 38,70.

Your face looks familiar.
You remind me of someone.
Really?
Yeah.
Of who?
Here, keep the change.
Thank you.
The future of the new Russia.

Youíll be doing well
in some 10 or 15 years.
Itís yours for 3 rubles!

Whatís that youíre
dragging out of the house?
Stole it from the kids?
I donít have any kids. Only a wife.
Okay, let me have a look.
Is it working, at least?
Of course!
Is there any film for it?
Yeah.
Did you bite the fork off?
No, I put it on a flat-iron.
All right.
Is everything intact? Okay, unload it.
Holy Molly! Okay, Iím off.
You should...
What?

Find some pack animals
to carry all that stuff.
Come on, hurry up.

Vasya, Iíll find him! You
know me, I can find anyone!
Here, here...
Hey there, Vasiliy!
Donít you recognize me?
Be more specific, mister.
No?
Show me the passport.
Do you have a passport with you?
What a strict guy you are.
There! Thereís your passport!
Kotov?
Yeah, Kotov.
Arenít you the...
Howís your wart? Has it healed yet?
What wart?
The one you tore open with a bast wisp?

You couldnít wait. You were
going to that date with Sveta.

And she didnít put
out that night, anyway!
Remember it, Vasya?

What about how we would steal
apples from our neighbor Vitya?
And then he got out and shot salt at us!

And then we bathed our asses
in the river for two hours.
Thatís when you got that wart.
Come on, Vasya!

When are you going to
repair my flashy glasses?
The ones you sat on when you were drunk?
Why donít you say something?
Zhenya?
Thatís me!

George, it is very cruel to
tell a person when they will die.

You see, if Mila knew
when she was going to die...
Thatís a new load of suffering!
I can see all that.
Thereís something else I want to know.
Why did she keep secrets from me?

And who was it? Who was that
person that was so important to her?

Well, now? Have you seen anything?
Have you found anything out?
Is anything becoming clearer now?
Thatís the thing, nothing is clearer!
I canít imagine Mila with anyone.
Well, with someone else...
Vasya, letís go to the cemetery.
What for?
Come on, letís go.
Okay.
Good beer.
What are you doing? Youíre driving!
All right, letís go.
Vasya, say hello to your dad for us.

The fifth... There, look.
Theyíre going to bury her here.

Next to another grave.
No plaque, no cross.
See? Itís not there yet.

And that... Angel says...
I donít know his name...

Well, itís going to appear
there soon. Two or three weeks.
Zhenya, well...
I donít think she had... has anyone.
Could it be a relative?

What relative? She
didnít have any relatives!

Her father is buried in the
regional center. Her mother, too.
Even if itís a relative,

an uncle or an aunt or
something, all right?
Why didnít she tell me?
Itís not like she can just leave me out!

Why did she tell our son,
our daughter, but not me?
And as if that wasnít enough,

she didnít even want
them to tell me! Why? Huh?

It means that that someone was
important to her. Like I give a...
I understand.
Whoís going to be buried there?
Vasya, promise me!

If I donít find out
anything really soon,

youíll come to me ñ I mean,
young me ñ and tell me everything!

Everything! And youíll
warn me, as a friend.
That Mila has someone else. Got it?

Youíll tell me everything,
all about that guy!

I canít promise you that.
Let them live in peace.
Donít pester them.

Iím muddle-headed as it is
because of all this stuff!
Promise me, you bastard!
Get your hands off of me!
Letís go.
Iím not going any further... so yeah.

Why not? Wonít you even come
in? Have a sip of compote?

What for, Zhenya? We
donít know each other.
What are you going to tell her?

Donít know... Weíll think of
something. Like, we met by accident.

Why are you doing this? Zhenya,
come on! Leave them alone!
Easy for you to say, Vasya.
You donít want to help me.
What choice do you leave me? Huh?
Only to tell Mila who I am.

I know. Youíre jealous.
But thereís a line.
Youíve got to understand.
This is selfish. Come on, Zhenya!

Vasya, Vasya! And to lie to
me for 25 years isnít selfish?
Think about it!

All right, you go. I have
some business with Mila anyway.

Iíll come over in five
minutes. Thatís where we ìmeet.î
What kind of business?
Zhenya!

The important thing is that you
donít do any monkey business!
Othello...

All right, Iíll come
over in five minutes.
Iíll come over in five minutes.

Ivan Kapitonovich, why did
you have to spend so much?
Come on, now! It was nothing.
Itís not even comfortable!

Yes it is. The man of the
house should have tools.

Now, how do we teach that
man of the house to use them?
Are you talking about Zhenya?
Who else?

Ivan Kapitonovich, he
knows how to do everything!
You have no idea how great he is.
Itís just that he never has the time.
Yeah, never has the time.
Look! Do you remember?

There used to be ones like
that when we were kids.

Some wino kept bugging
me, ìtake it! Take it!î
All right, Iíll fix it,

thereís going to be
cartoons for Igor and Lena.
Thank you. Vasiliy! Hello!
Hello!
Whatís that you have there?

Potatoes. Canít let my best
friendís family starve, can I?
Vasya...
You have guests?
What thoughtful friends you have!
Especially when the husband isnít there.

Ivan Kapitonovich, meet
Zhenyaís best friend.
And this is...
...Zhenyaís dad.
Dad?
Yep.
Pleased to meet you. Vasiliy.
Ivan Kapitonovich.

I see now why the fatherís
watching us so strictly.

Mila, Iím so thirsty! Do
you have anything to drink?
Thereís some compote.
Compote, great! Yes, please.
Yes?
Yes, please.
Iíll bring it right away.
Thank you very much.
Thanks for the potatoes!

Zhenya, donít you think about
telling her anything! Got it?
Got it, got it. Look, Vasya, what if...
What if what? What?
Nothing, nothing.
Come on.
Take it.
This, you drink here.

And this is a jar for
you to take home, Vasya.
Thank you! For me?
For the potatoes. I donít know.
Come on, Mila. I donít...
Mila, come on.
I put my heart into it, Vasya!
I love your compote. Thank you, Mila.

No, thank you. Zhenya asked
you to do it, didnít he?
No, no. Zhenya doesnít know.
Let Zhenya work in Vladivostok in peace.
Drink it, donít be shy.
Thank you!
I think Iíll run off to work now,

or else theyíll tear
my shoulder straps off.
Here you go.
Thank you very much.
No, thank you.
I was very glad to meet you.
See you!
Looks just like Zhenya, doesnít he?
He does.
See you!
And again, thank you, Vasya. Bye!

Theyíve been friends since
when they were children.
I see.
Quite a working man we have here.
Hello.
Hello.
Zoya Semenovna.

You even know my name.
Did Mila tell you?
Yep.
Interesting. What else did she tell you?
Nothing.
I heard we had guests.

I thought Iíd go meet
them, so here I am.
Well, good job. What can I say?
Itís a good job, youíve done a good job.

Which is more than I
can say about your son.
Why do you dislike him?
Itís not that I dislike him,

but heís not that
great around the house.
Heís more into business trips.
He loves to work! Far away from home.

Even if no oneís sending
him on a business trip,
heís just begging for one!

He wants to go to the back
of the beyond just so much.
All right, enough about sad things.
Iíve brought you some stuff.
One minute...
Varya!
What do you want?
Come here!
Coming.

We wonít manage without
your gifted hands.
We have to lay the table.
Leave me alone, Iím working!
Be right there!
Mom!

You can work all you
want later, come on.
Mom!
What?

Could you be a little more
quiet? I just tucked the kids in.

Okay, not like Iíve ever woken
your children. Grab the bag.
Iíll get it inside.
Why did you carry it, then?
All right.
We have everything we need, Mom.
My lovely grandchildren.
Letís go.
If anyone loves it, itís the grandkids.
Although they donít look like me.
They look more like you and your son.
Wow, so beautiful.
Ivan Kapitonovich.
Yes?
Come to the table.
Iím going.

Come on, everyone gather
up. Itís getting cold!
Letís eat it while itís still hot.

He must think we have a
feast like this every day.
So true.

And we canít even remember
the last time we got together!
Right, girls?
So true.
But for a guest like this,
it would be a shame not to get together.

And since you are
basically the only man here,
let me court you like I mean it.
Mom!
I donít know, I donít drink.
Why drink vodka?
Well, what else is there?
What, like, at all?
Sometimes. But as a rule, no.

Attaboy! Which is more than
I can say about your daddy.
Mom!

Heíll suckle on the bottle, then
play the balalaika all night long.
Come on, then! Pour it, pour it!
What are you waiting for, Mila?
Donít be shy, Ivan Kapetonovich.
Itís all simple around here.
Varya, a shot of vodka?
A shot of vodka.
Iím not drinking.
Zoya Semenovna!
Youíre so boring.
Iíve been meaning to ask you,

why do you shorten her
name to Milka all the time?

Your daughter has such a
beautiful name! Mila, Milushka...
And you go: ìMilka, Milka.î

Of course itís beautiful,
I gave her that name myself.

Iíve never been too fuzzy-wuzzy
with her. Right, baby?

And it was the right thing to
do. Look how great she turned out!
Okay, thatís it, stop it.
Except the wrong guy got her.
What I want to say is...
Say it.

Iím glad, really glad
that Iím here. Really.
Iím amazed.
Weíre glad that you came, too!
Letís drink.
Why wouldnít we be glad?

Ivan Kapitonovich, you
must have children, too,
back where you live?
Yeah, I do, I do.
Youíve had so much fun.
A daughter and a son.

Really? You live the
way you want to, right?
And now you come here, and...
Mom!

What a daughter-in-law
heís got!
Stop it!
His sonís all grown up. Right?
All true, all true.
And the grandchildren!
All of this is true.

Beautiful kids running
around! Smiling, clean! Right?
What are your childrenís names?
Grandmaís taken good care of them.
Mom!
Wait a second, let me finish!
The kidsí names are Lena and Igor.

Just like Zhenyaís and mine!
What a coincidence, huh?
Yes.
To children, then. Right?

Come on! To Lenas, to Igors!
And to my beloved daughter.

Ivan Kapitonovich, your children
must be all grown up, huh?

Yeah, theyíre adults. My
daughterís married now.
And my son is in Saint Petersburg,

about to graduate from
the Military Academy,
heís almost an officer already.
Where?
Did you hear what he said?

I mean, in Leningrad,
yeah! In Leningrad.
Did you hear what he said?
In Leningrad.
What is this, 1917?
Mom...
What a great liqeur I brought.
Tell me, how do you like the roses?
Incredible.
Yeah, every petal...

Ivan Kapitonovich must be
tired. He should get some rest.
Come on, why would I get tired?
Mushrooms?
Iíll be back...
Some herring?
Excuse me for a minute.
Did you hear it?
Hear what?
Heís weird.
Heís not weird.
Mom, you say everyoneís weird.
He overworked himself.

Look how much heís
done around the house!
Hey there, girls.
Hello, hello.
Whatís the occasion?
I brought you new newspapers.
And rumors, too?

Rumors, huh! Whoís the
first to listen to them?
Sit down.
Youíve got a guest?
Itís my birthday.
Oh! Right!
That guest? Everyone knows by now!
There just isnít a letter! I mean...

No, no, no! I still
have to make the rounds!

Come on, not like youíre
going to fall off yer bike.
No, Mila, really. Itís the Far East.

Imagine how long itílll
take that letter to arrive.
Heíll get here before the letter does.
Iím completely serious.
Why does she worry so much?
Girls, do I have a story for you!
So, thereís a rumor going around.
I think itís all true!

So, some hypnotist
showed up around here.
Heís a drifter.

Heíll tell you all the
truth, predict your future,
all that stuff.
He diverts peopleís attention,

and then their jewelry
and money are gone.
Jesus Christ.
Iím telling you!
And I believe it.
Seriously.
Mila.
Huh?

Listen to me. Go check
the money in the cabinet.
Mom, itís all there.
I told you to go check!
You go check, if you want it so bad.

I will, my dear child,
what else can I do?
What was that?
Who is that? Whoís there at your place?
Thatís Zhenyaís dad. He came over.
Really?
Hello, Shura.
Hello.
Iíll go wash my hands.
Well?
Looks all right.
Well, thank God!
Are you happy?
I am now.
Listen, that relative of yours,
he came up and said: ìHello, Shura.î
How did he know Iím Shura?
No, really?
And the Saint Petersburg thing?

He says: ìMy son is studying
in Saint Petersburg.î
Right? KGB!
Girls, this is KGB!
No!
Why not?

Because if he were KGB, he wouldnít
have said ìSaint Petersburg.î
Girls, that was a test.
Thank you.
Maybe I could help you, after all?

No thaks, Ivan Kapitonovich,
Iíll handle it from here.

What? Itís pretty
fitting for a KGB agent.
Thatís right.

Yesterday Shura was
confident you were KGB
because you called her by name.

Iíve told you already: I
heard it at a bus station.

Someone called out and
it stuck in my memory.
Thatís what I told her!

Thatís all right, we
have to be vigilant.
Mila!
Mila!
Whatís wrong?
No, nothing. Itís all right.
I want to have a go.
Can I please sit over there?
Letís go, letís go.
Igor, will you let Lena have a go?
Whatís the matter?
Letís let Lena have a go. Okay?
Come on.
No.

Maybe we should get the
toys. Weíre going back soon.
Get all the toys...
Whoís past their bedtime?
Mila, I wanted to ask you.

How many shelves to
we put in the cupboard?
Three or four?

Ivan Kapitonovich, youíve
done so much already.
Come on, now!
Letís not have this conversation.
I owe you for living here anyway.
Itís just that...

Like I said: Zhenya wonít
be very pleased, Iím afraid.
Yes he will!.

When he comes here, weíll sit
down and talk it out like men.
Weíll make peace.
So whatís it going to be, three or four?
Let it be four, then.
Thatís it!
Thereís going to be a lot of jars here.

And Iím going to make
some apple jam, too.
Yeah.

But it seems to me these kids
donít let you work at all.
Come on, no!
So... Letís go play behind the table?
All right!
All right, letís go.
Careful.

We play for a little bit,
itís their bedtime already.
Letís go! Igor! Come on.
Iím not going to sleep.

Youíre not going to sleep?
Okay, you arenít. And...
Sheís cawwing me a pwincess!
Iím Igow!
What is she calling you now?
Pwincess!
Iíll show you, ìprincess.î
Come on, take Igorís hand.
Damn it!
Get your toys.
Weíre going home now.

What happened there?
Did you get a splinter?
There, right under the nail.
Let me see...
Thatís deep! Going to need a needle.
Really?
Letís go to the kitchen. Iíll help you.

Itís okay, Iíll clip the
nail with some scissors.
Come on, come on.

Never did know how to
do it with the left hand.

Itís just amazing how
much you look like Zhenya.
Let me help you.
Come on.
Does it hurt?
No.
What are you doing?
What?
What the hell was that?
What the hell was what?
Donít you play dumb! Donít you get it?

For shame! Youíre an elderly
man, trying to grope me!

And you wanted someone
your own age, huh?

What is this? What right
do you have to insult me?

Who do you think I am? I
didnít even know you a week ago!

I took you in with open
arms, and what did you do?

If itís like that, then get out. Go
live in a hotel until Zhenya comes back!

And you, youíre going to take
somebody here, arenít you?
Do you have anyone in mind? Tell me!

What are you talking
about? What is this?
Are you crazy?
You thought Iíd never find out, huh?
Find out about what?
My dear, I know everything!
Iím not ìyour dearî! Got it?
And I donít want to see you anymore.

Get out of here! Live wherever
you want until Zhenya comes back!
Mila!
Mila!
Come on, can you dance?
From Zhenya?!

Who else? Got here from
the Far East itself.
Thank you, Shura! Thank you!
All right, all right.
Youíre still here?
Itís all lies.
Look, Iíve had enough of that from you.
Hello, dear Mila.
I miss you and our kids very much.
But the situation at work has changed.

I still have to deal
with the train cars.

Iím going to have to
stay here another week.

Itís all lies. And it has
nothing to do with cars.
How do you know what the letter says?
Because itís me, Mila! Me!
What do you mean, me?
I am your husband! Your Zhenya!
Well? Canít you feel it?

Look at me carefully. Donít
you recognize me? Mila...
Donít you recognize me? Huh?

Zhenya! Zhenya, what is
this? How did it happen?
Well?
Zhenya, is that you?
Yes!

What happened to you?
How did you get so old?
What did they do to you there?
Itís not a ìthereî, Mila.
Where Iím from, thereís no you anymore.
And, in a day you... died.
At 4:30 AM. In my arms.
Forgive me.
You were everything to me. And I...

Itís like the air: you breath
it and never think about it.
I hardly ever told you that I love you.

And when I did, I was
forcing myself to do it.
I was afraid. Afraid, all my life.

Afraid of commitment,
of love. Of betrayal.

Iíve been like that
since when I was a child.
You know, when father left Mom and me,

she handed me over to a
foster home and disappeared.

And only when you were no
more I realized everything.

Oh, how I miss you. I realized
that when you were next to me,

you were the most valuable,
most important thing in my life.
And I totally missed it.
Forgive me.
Forgive me.
I thought youíd be there forever.

Come on, come on. There
you go, just a bit more.
Itís almost healed.

Yep, itís healing. Thatís
going to leave a huge scar.

Yeah. I think itís going to
stay there your whole life.
Great.
It looks like the letter ìLî.
ìLî...
L is for Love! Love! Do you love me?
Do you?
I asked you first!
And why should I answer?

Youíre going to stay silent
when itís your turn, anyway.
Right?

I think Iím going to die having
never heard you say you love me.

Bite your tongue! Come on! I
donít want to hear you say ìdieî.

I want to live with you happily
ever after. Did you hear me?

Mila, letís go inside.
Youíll get the cold.
Why did you tell me all that?

Why did I tell you? Because
I want to change everything.

I want to save you. Thereís a
law called the Law of Obstruction.
It keeps you from meeting yourself.
If I stay here, with you,

Young Yevgeniyís fate
will begin to change
and heíll never come back here. Never!

Because he doesnít deserve
you. Itís all his fault.

Did you hear me? His! The
fact that you got sick.
That...
even as we speak heís cheating on you.
He never did really love you. Never!
And I do! Iíll make you happy.
Donít even think about it.
Mila, listen. Come on! Look at me!
Come on, Iím not an old man, Iím strong.

I know a lot of things. I
can quickly achieve things

that would take him
and the others years.

Everythingís changing around
us. Everything! The government...

Iím going to take up business.
I know how to make money,

where to invest it, buy up all
their shares, their damn vouchers!

I know what to do with them.
See? I can do everything.

Everythingís going to be
great. Iíll make you happy. I...
Mila! Mila!
Give me the photos.
Go away!
Go get some sleep.
And you?
See, the grave isnít there.

You know what I was
thinking about yesterday?

The day I got back from that
Vladivostok business trip.
I remember her face,
I remember seeing something in her eyes...

apart from love, I could
see some kind of guilt.

Vasya, sheís not telling
me the whole story.

Did you tell her? Did
you tell her who you are?
Yeah, Vasya, I did.
Did you tell her sheís going to die?
By accident! I didnít mean to, Vasya!

How do you do something
like that by accident?
Well... You see, Iím a human being!
She... Sheís walking around, and I...
I want to grab her, hug her...

Well, and it so happened
that I... touched her...
And sheís thinking Iím his dad!
You know, Yevgeniyís.
I thought she was going to kick me out,

and she did. Well, so
I told her everything.
By accident!
What, that was the reason?

And thatís why you had to
tell her she was going to die?

Vasya, that Zhenya of yours
never loved her, never!
And I do!
Anyway, I want to stay with her!

Because when sheís with me, I
wonít let her die, Vasya, I woní!

So thatís why you told her
she was going to die, right?
Yes!
And what did she tell you?
Nothing so far.

Why are you so sure sheís
going to stay with you?
Imagine that she stays with him.

Sheíll never be happy! She
knows when sheís going to die!

She even knows why. How
do you live with that?

How do you live with that?
Have you thought about that?

No, you havenít! You still
donít understand a thing!
Vasya...
I have nothing to talk to you about.
Vasya!

Okay, Lena, take them
off. Take the dress off.
Shoot.
Come here.
And then, towards the evening...
Who got here before us?
Aunt Varyaís here!
Come in.

Come evening, Iíll have
fixed the filmstrip projector.
Weíll hang a white sheet on the wall,
thatís going to be our screen.

Weíll watch some fun pictures,
interesting cartoons. Right?
And I wonít go to bed?

Good girl, Lena, taking
her clothes off by herself.
Well... I donít know.

Are you going to watch the
cartoons in the evening?
The cartoons?
I am!
There!

I am! Yeah, Iím going
to watch the cartoons...
Oh, hello!
Hello, aunt Varya.

That weather! Itís like itís
the spring. Just amazing!
My sparrows! Look what I brought you.

Weíre going to have a
nice cultural program.
So get some sleep.

Get some sleep, then
weíll watch the cartoons.

There, Granddad is
going to show it to you.
Thank you!

Yeah, Iím thinking about taking
a walk to the river or something.
Take it, then.
Itís kind of boring to go alone.
Take Milaís mom. Sheís at home.
She is?

The riverfront caf?s are
so interesting. Try them!

Iíve been thinking
about ways to get Mila
to leave the house and take a walk.

Sheís in there with the
children all day long,
she never really relaxes. Huh, Mila?
Mila, how about we go for a walk?
Aunt Varya, can you watch the children?

Aunt Varyaís got things
to take care of herself!

No, sure, Iíll watch
them, whatís it to me?
There you go.
And you, you go!
Go on, before I change my mind!
Hey there, traveler.
Hello, Shura.
Well? Donít you feel any shame?
Why?

Why?! One letter over a
whole month, Zhenya! Tut-tut.

I see you postal
workers know everything.
Yes, we do.
For shame, Shura, for shame!

Come on, go, your
wifeyís waiting for you.
Dad! Dad!
Dad! Dad!

Why didnít you come clean
about cheating on me, then?
I wanted to!

I was thinking about
it the entire way back.

ìIíll get there and tell her
everything. Iíll come clean.î

And then, near the house, when
I walked into the front yard,
you threw yourself into my arms, crying.
Crying? What was I crying about?
I donít know.

But in your face, in
your eyes, there were...

I canít describe it! It
was both love and pain.

I couldnít, I just couldnít
tell it to you then.

But I decided to never
come clean with you.
And that Iíll never cheat on you!

And now, when I think about the
way you looked at me, I think...

Tell me, is there
someone very dear to you?
I mean, deep down in your heart,
could there be someone like that?
Yes, there could be.
Do you have someone like that?
Yes.
And who is it?
My dad.
Wait heís... Buried in a different place.
What do you mean? Wait...
Wait, dad, what is...
Sorry, I...
What, he died? When?
What are you doing out here in the cold?
I went out to buy a newspaper.
Bought some bread, just in time.
Letís go.
Zhenya will be back soon.
You should be going.
Wait! We have another week.
Heíll only be back in a week.
I want to be alone!

I still have to muster up
the strength to meet him.
Why donít you want to stay with me?
Because itís impossible!
Why?
Well, how do you propose we do it?
All right. But we can leave somewhere!
Where?
Wherever. To Crimea, if you want to.

Remember? You would
dream about it yourself.
Weíll take Igor, Lena, and leave!
No!
Mila!
Tell me, you do love me, right?
Tell me.
Just explain it to me.
Whatís wrong? Iíll... Iíll...
Iíll try to correct it!
I beg you, go away!

Where would I go to,
huh? I have nowhere to go!
No one wants me there! I have no one!

No one needs me. The kids...
They have their own lives.
Iím alone there. Youíre not there! Mila!
Mila, I only love you! I love you! You!

I canít... I donít want
to lose you again. I...
Get up.
No, itís ridiculous! So he goes:

ìI want to go take a walk
down to the river with Mila.î
Why Mila? Why not you?

No, Iím telling you. Thereís
something wrong about it.
Look at him! Bastard.
Wonít you listen to yourself?

Youíre only thinking
about yourself again!
Have you thought about me, even once?
How can you stay here?
Canít you see that you canít do that?
That this is wrong?
Holly Molly! What is going on here?
Wow, that is a real mess.
Bread lying on the floor...
My dear child, have you lost your mind?
Mom!
What are you doing?
Calm down! Youíve got it all wrong!
Iíve got it wrong?!
Mila!
No, Iíve got it all right! ìMilaî what?
Wait a second, Iíll explain everything!

Oh yeah? Explain it
to your son, lover boy!
Got the hots for the young one, huh?
Mila, I want to stay with you.
He wants...
Shut up!
Can you hear me?
Sheís my wife! Come on, tell her!
Calm down!
Tell her!

What are you doing? What
are you talking about?
Tell her, come on!
Calm down!
Tell her!
Go on, get out of here! Go!
Have you lost your mind?
Tell her!
Come on, tell her who I am!
Get out!
Lover boy!
What are you standing around for?
Donít touch me.
Oh my God! Jesus!
What? What?

You say another word to
him and Iíll strangle you.
Got it?
Like a grave.

If I stay with you,
everything will change.

Itíll all be good. I
wonít let you suffer.

Iíll take care of you the
way that young idiot canít!
So funny to hear you speak.
Funny how?

Itís like itís him and
not you. But it is you!
Why should I believe you?

Yevgeniy Ivanovich,
you canít do that. No!
Goddamn... Damn it!
Quiet! Quiet!
Great help you were!
Calm down.

Why the hell did you do that?
To make me suffer even more?

Tell me! What has changed?
What have I learned? Well?
Calm down!

You wanted to make me
fall in love with my wife.

Like, ìyeah, suffer
some more, you bastard.î

Right? Why did you put
me here? Huh? Tell me!

I sent you there so that
you donít commit suicide.
Or youíll never, ever see Mila again.
How do you know?
What the hell can you know?
Iíll do as I please afterwards.
No!
Go to hell!
No!
Go to hell!
No!
Go to hell!
Iím just like you! Donít you get it?

I couldnít bear it when
my wife and daughter

were killed in an accident.
Iím killed myself, too!

Now, if you do kill
yourself, youíll never --

do you understand?
Never! ñ see your wife.

Instead youíll suffer, just
like I am now, just like me!
Youíll talk to dumbasses like yourself!

The stubborn donkeys like
the one youíre being now!

You think I want to save
your soul, to save your life?

I donít give a damn!
If I fail this mission,

Iíll never see my family.
The same will happen to you!
What are you feeling right now? Despair?
Hopelessness?
No! Thatís selfishness! Get it now?
I thought theyíd be there forever, too.

And when they passed away,
I didnít know what to do.

I wanted to be with them.
I wanted to feel good again.

Do you see now? Me! I
only thought about myself.
Just like you are now!
Grandma, look out!
Fell asleep behind the wheel.

Ready. We have to take
him to get identified.
No need. I know him.
All the better.

Who would have thought
heroes still exist?
Vasya, will you...
Will you help me bury him?

Of course. Me, the boys,
weíll all help. Sure.

Yeah, but he left for us
all. Let it be that way.
Of course, I understand. Sure.

Itís just that... I donít
know how to say it.
This isnít Zhenyaís dad.
I know. This is Zhenya. He told me.
I thought it was...

You know what, Iíll write
a letter for Lena and Igor.

Please give it to them when
Iím gone. Just not right away.

Of course, I understand.
Okay. Iíll do it.
Thank you.
Hello.
Uncle Vasya, this is Lena.

Our dad is missing. He hasnít
been there for a full day.
Is he at your place?

No, he isnít. But thereís
no need to look for him.

Lena, Iíll come over in a
moment and tell you everything.
My dear daughter and son!
This is a letter from me, your mother.

Uncle Vasya is going to give it
to you when your dad is no more.
Donít look for him.

Heís buried in the grave next
to which I asked you to bury me.
Youíll understand everything

when youíve reached
the end of this letter.

Youíll see why I couldnít share
this secret with you before.

Know that I only love
two things greatly:

you, my dear children, and
your father, my beloved husband.

May your sadness be light.
Live long and be happy!
I feel guilty.
Why?

Because if I never let the
secret out that it was Momís wish
to be buried next to that old grave,

Dad would never have gone
to the past and died there.
Donít think about.
It must have been arranged that way.
Youíre not guilty of anything.

Uncle Vasyaís right.
Itís not your fault.
Marina, come here!
And whoís that?
I hope itís my future wife!
Hello.
Meet Lena, my wise sister.
Marina.
Pleased to meet you.

And this is Uncle Vasya,
friend of our parentsí.
And a good friend of ours, too.
Pleased to meet you.

Why havenít you introduced
her to us before?
You see, how do I put it...
This is an incredible story.
Many years ago, when I was little,

Yevgeniy Ivanovich saved
me and my grandmother,
but died himself.

When I grew up, I started
visiting this grave here.
You are that little girl?

Yes! Weíre very grateful
to him. Both me and Grandma.
Except she passed away a long time ago.
Once I came here and met Igor.
Thatís how we met.
The strangest things can happen in life.
You know, I think Iíll get going now.
Iíll give you a lift to the city.
Right! Donít mind if I do.
Uncle Vasya! See you!
Bye!
Bye, little sister! See you!
Well, weíll be going now.
Goodbye!
Goodbye!
What a nice statue.
Yeah, it is nice.
Hello!

comments.text:
в сюжете только неувязка.если бы не было  безымянной могилы,то он бы не 
поперся в прошлое и не погиб бы там соответственно и могилы этой бы не было﻿
comments.author: Alexey Sorichinsky

comments.text: Что то в этом фильме загадочное и мудрое.﻿
comments.author: Наталия Алёх

comments.text:
Очень поучительный и душевный фильм.
Смотрела на одном дыхании.
Спасибо его создателям, за ту сказку, о которой мы часто мечтаем, сожалея о 
сделанных ошибках, без возможности и права на их исправление. Хотя порой 
готовы сознательно заплатить собственной жизнью, лишь бы был шанс! Но увы...
﻿
comments.author: Надежда Бондарец

comments.text:
Да. Что имеем - не храним, а потеряем - плачем... Очень хороший фильм. С 
душой. Со смыслом. Есть о чем подумать. Смотрела, думала о своей жизни... 
Спасибо большое! <3﻿
comments.author: Ирина Диогенова

comments.text:
Не пожалела, что посмотрела фильм. Очень фильм понравился и Константин 
Милованов  сыграл просто на одном дыхании.﻿
comments.author: Dmitriy Kurilo

comments.text: Милые герои, душевная история. Жаль, что такое бывает только в сказках...﻿
comments.author: Viktoria L

comments.text:
Подскажите, пожалуйста, где скачать песню "Ты и Я" которая играет в начале 
фильма?
Автор текста и исполнитель Александр Котов, музыка Иван Розин... перерыл 
интернет не могу найти никак... Спасибо Большое ﻿
comments.author: aksdhfeiurytdhfklg

comments.text:
Нормальный, просмотрел с удовольствием. Из мира сказок. Как 50-летний мужик 
погиб ~ 25 лет назад пятидесятилетним мужиком.И ведь неясно, куда бы 
повернулась дорожка, если бы он остался с ней. Может в 10 раз тяжелее.﻿

comments.text: Самоубийцы никогда АД не смогут покинуть всегда будут гореть﻿

очень грустный и хороший фильм, после просмотра печаль вселенская на душе,

comments.text:
Измена? Люди не принадлежат, как вещи, друг-другу. Это все только

для людей из "коробки".﻿

comments.text: боже мой стало так тоскливо,на душе пусто... хочется рыдать....﻿

Отличный фильм.Спасибо создателям.Есть над чем задуматься.Что имеем не

фильм смотрела на одном дыхании. Необычный сюжет. Фильм со смыслом. Спасибо

comments.text:
Хороший фильм, спасибо авторам. Очень важная тема - как надо любить  и

comments.text: безумно понравился фильм! просто нет слов...﻿

comments.text: Всё как в жизни, только назад не вернешься...﻿

comments.text:
Огромное спасибо создателям этого прекрасного фильма, хотя слезы чуть не

Вечности не остаться одинокими.﻿

comments.text:
Отличный фильм!!! С огромной сверхзадачей, которую выполнил в полном 
объеме!!! Очень полезный фильм с житейской точки зрения, построения 
 взаимоотношений  между мужчиной и женщиной!!! Спасибо авторам фильма и 
актерам,так здорово сыгравшим в нем!!!﻿

comments.text: Прекрасный фильм, я тоже плакала посмотреть советую﻿
comments.author: Дулма Дашнимаева

comments.text:
Спасибо, очень хороший и поучительный фильм.
Все-таки хорошо, что мы при жизни не знаем дату своей смерти.  ﻿
comments.author: asdf54u

comments.text:
Идея обыграна во многих фильмах. Только непонятно- зачем все это? Жизнь с 
тем, кто все равно не доверяет и после смерти. Измены, непонимание, 
одиночество вдвоем. Только ради того, чтобы он на пару недель вернулся 
назад, поругался со всеми, сказал, что всю жизнь был неправ- и убежал к 
своей же смерти от безысходности. Тупиковое ответвление вероятностей) 
Вернутся, чтобы снова ошибаться, сделать больнее, ничего не исправить.. За 
что ангелу-то зачет?))﻿
comments.author: starsestra

comments.text: Потрясающий фильм.Жаль...Но так бывает и в жизни.﻿
comments.author: Ирина Шиманская

comments.text:
Очень хороший фильм-сюжет чем-то похож на американский фильм "Путешествие 
во времени".﻿

comments.text: Хороший фильм. Так хочется во все поверить... Спасибо!﻿
